BETTY AMOS IS DELEGATE
TO STUDENTS GATHERING

While the most of us were spend-
ing the last few days of our Christ-
mas vacation in our homes, there
was meeting in New York City the
National Council of Christian As-
sociations, better known as the C.
C. Aâ€™s., composed of representative
students from states as far west as
California and as far south as
Texas.
This year saw the first time that
any college in the Mid-Atlantic di-
vision of the C. C. A. has been re-
presented and Maryland feels that
it was well represented by Betty
Amos, who went to the Council for
the University,
The meeting tvered two im-
portant question! . First a deter-
mination of the attitude of students
all over the country toward the de-
cisions reached at Princeton re-
garding' the World Court, and sec-
ond, and most important, a deter-
mination of their attitude concern-
ing the very definite stand against
all denominations and all creeds
taken by the Conference of Inter-
denominational Students at Evans-
ton, 111. The last mentioned con-
ferencj was called by the church
boards of the country and included
discussions in which none could
participate except the students.
They reached the conclusion that
there should be one church only,
a Unified Church, allowing absolute
freedom of thought to all.

The C. C. A. that the group
meeting at Evanston had done
nothing really constructive, that is,
that they could better have discus-
sed how students can work through
various churches or what demands
they might make of the church,
rather than merely discussing
faults of the churches and hastily
deciding against denominational-
isms and creeds. They felt that
that should be the attitude of the
C. C. A. toward the decision, and
a
also that if the absolute conviction
of (he students was against denoxni-
nationalism, they should agree to
give up all Christian organizations
in the colleges and work through
this one unification, as they are
asking the churches to do. It was
the opinion of the council that the

present student generation is not
ready for such a big step, even
though it might bo right.
Another item in the program of
the meeting was a thorough study
of the present educational system.
This was referred to a committee
who will work on it and give their
report at the next annual meeting.
U. of M.
